The claim that the Ancient Egyptians invented geometry and the Ancient Greeks merely plagiarized it is a complex issue with no definitive consensus among historians and archaeologists.  While it's true that both civilizations had significant advancements in geometry, attributing the entire field to one civilization and accusing the other of outright plagiarism is an oversimplification that ignores the nuances of historical development.

@TheQuestion-o6v  what the Greeks had going for them was writing stuff down and talk about it. The Egyptians were very practical people. The Greeks, to an extent, were more academic. It was smart to trade knowledge with other cultures. And then look at it from a theoretical viewpoint in order to move the subject forward. What they apparently did very poorly was credit their sources.

The Universe is not exactly flat, our fundamental understanding is flawed. It's a sphere. The Big expansion, not the big bang. Has James Webb or Hubble spotted any cube planets or stars yet? All these 3 and 4 dimentional objects aren't what I consider accurate. I'm currently seeing planes as x, y and z. One dimentional planes or frames. X as horizontal West to East, visually perceptible topologicaly. Y as vertical, north to south,  percievable front facing. Z as back to front, the arrow of time and perhaps the concept of consciousness. Each of the 3 planes or axis have 4 corners,  combining into 1 outward projected reality that forms the curvature of space. Higgs field gives consciousness most likely, not mass... That would make consciousness as the 4th dimension, perhaps the holographic reality a layer on that..Generally speaking, multiple dimensions exist within that framework. It gets very complicated very quickly, but you could see our physical reality as being the 5th dimension, I do for the most part and I do believe it to be utterly important that we view the Universe in the same way we view consciousness and dimentionality and maintain the same number of dimensions throughout. @khaizharris  HUH
You could say the same for lines, they have no width, so how can they add up to become a plane? Strange things happen when the infinitesimal meets infinity.
@ProfessorDaveExplains  there is nothing like infinitesimal , infinitesimal things have dimensions.like infinitesimal areA , infinitesimal length etc . But points have no dimensions at all
@ProfessorDaveExplains  you can't compare point with infinitesimal
The width of a line is the same as the width of a point, zero. You absolutely can compare them. Same with the depth of a plane, line, or point. Again, all zero.
@ProfessorDaveExplains  I am not saying that you are right in this context I saying you can't say that point is infinitesimal small
But you can. Infinitesimal means smaller than any feasible measurement, but not zero, such that it can't be distinguished from zero. That's a point.
@ProfessorDaveExplains    if a point has 0 dimensions doesnt that make it non existent ?
@mar-ww3if  No, 0-dimensional doesn't mean nonexistent.

You cannot be aware of dimensions without more than one reference point. If I give you one object and ask you a question about its size, relative to a set, while you know nothing of any other object in a set, you cannot say if it is big or small. Once I give you another object you can then say "hey this is smaller than object a". When we say if something is big or small it is in reference to things we have seen in our life. Dimensions are measurements. Measurements are relative. Points are references and therefore individually have no dimension, but if you have 2 together you have 1 dimension and if you have 3 or more you can potentially have 2 dimensions etc to our maximal ability to see which is 3 dimensions.
Understanding dimension is key to understanding the idea, dimension is a measurement.
The only problem is Euclid did not explicitly define dimension in Elements.
